The Sakurajima volcano on Japan's Kyushu island poses a "growing threat", researchers at the University of Bristol say. The Japanese archipelago, which sits on the Pacific "Ring of fire", has more than 100 volcanoes. Sakurajima regularly spews ash and there are many small explosions there each year, with the latest eruption being in February. It is closely monitored by Japanese authorities and one of two volcanoes at Level 3 out of 5 levels in Japan's volcanic warning system, which means that people are warned not to to approach the volcano. Their first stop on a busy day of public engagements was a tour of the Giant's Causeway in County Antrim. The causeway formed when molten rock was forced through terrestrial fissures creating a lavastraphryon. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh then visited the nearby village of Bushmills to commemorate local soldier Robert Quigg. He was awarded the Victoria Cross for exceptional bravery during the Battle of Somme, having ventured into the line of fire to find his commanding officer. The royal couple unveiled a statue and commemorative stone, with his grandnephew, Leonard Quigg, delivering a brief address. They attended a reception at the Portrush Golf Club, hosted by the mayor of Causeway Coast and Glens Borough Council. Afterwards, they embarked on a nostalgic journey aboard a steam train from Coleraine, County Londonderry, to Bellarena. In Coleraine, substantial crowds gathered to welcome the couple as they boarded the five-car train built in 1932. They travelled to Bellarena, where the Queen inaugurated the new railway station of the village along with local schoolchildren. The Royal guests first traversed this historic railway line in 1953, the year of her coronation, when the original station had been operational for a century. Following recent infrastructure improvements, the Queen unveiled a plaque to mark the new development, while wellwishers lined the route, waving union flags and offering enthusiastic greetings. The launch of what was supposed to be its flagship model has turned into a fiasco for the world's largest smartphone maker. This unexpected transfer promises to inject fresh excitement into local cricket by bridging the gap between professional and amateur levels.

The #penuriecarburantdansunfilm hashtag, which literally translated to "fuel shortage in a film" became France's top tweet trend on Tuesday with over 5,000 tweets. A strike over new labour laws affects all eight of France's oil refineries with estimated 20 % of the stations dry or low in supplies. French social media users creatively reimagined film titles to reflect the shortage, renaming classics like Pulp Fiction to "Pump Friction" and Mad Max: Fury Road to "Mad Max: Bicycle Lane" The Fast and Furious franchise of Vin Diesel inspired variations such as "Last and Furious" and "Pas Fast Mais Furious", while other films like 8 Mile became "0 Mile" and "8 Miles A Pied" Kubrick's works were not spared, with Full Metal Jacket changed to "Fuel Metal Jacket" and references to Renault's Espace Minivan. User also incorporated Jerrycans with more jokey titles like "Tom and Jerrycan" and "Catch Me If You Jerrycan" with Drive becoming "Walk and Drive Pas". The creative wordplay highlighted the widespread impact of the 'fuel shortage on French daily life.

Among them was a vulnerable 17-year-old intercepted at the airport of Sydney, a chilling testament to the seductive power of extremist ideologies, according to Immigration Minister Peter Dutton. Mr. Dutton warned of the haunting and ever-increasing threat of young Australians being lured into the dark embrace of groups like Islamic State (IS). Special anti-terror teams, now vigilantly stationed at Australia's eight international airports since August, represent a desperate shield against this insidious recruitment. The intercepted teenager, on the precipice of being drawn into the savage conflict in the Middle East, was returned to the trembling custody of his parents as investigations delved into his troubled path. Just days earlier two Sydney brothers — mere teenagers themselves — were stopped at the same airport with their youthful dreams hijacked by radical propaganda. Despite the school's prudent reinstatement whispers of unease lingered in the home of concerned parents. Australia's anti-terrorism units have already responded with 85,000 individuals, a staggering number that highlights the threat. With about 90 citizens have already disappeared into the treacherous landscapes of Iraq and Syria and 20 have been tragically lost in the conflict, the nation faces a heartbreaking reality. The story of Jake Bilardi, a teenage Melbourne boy allegedly transformed into a suicide attacker, epitomizes this devastating journey -- a lonely soul manipulated into becoming what his father described as a "trophy" paraded by IS, a chilling symbol of vulnerability exploited. The law is determined: any Australian entering IS holdings without legitimate cause faces a potential decade behind bars, a stark deterrent against radicalization's arousal.

The amnesty applies to offences committed during the political turmoil after Mr. Thaksin's ouster in a coup d'état. The lower house passed the controversial bill in the early hours of Friday, with the bill advanced to the Senate. The opposition democrat party has warned that its passage will likely spark street protests. Despite the abstention of the party, the bill passed unanimously with 310 votes. The passage of the bill through the Senate remains uncertain as half of its members are appointed, although it could potentially occur as soon as next week which would likely produce further demonstrations. Advocates argue the bill will resolve the political divisions caused by the 2006 military coup that removed Mr. Thaksin from power, a period marked by significant unrest, including the occupation of Bangkok's main airport in 2008 and two months of protests in 2010 that resulted in approximately 90 deaths, mostly civilian protesters. Critics however contend that the amnesty would effectively shield human rights abuses from accountability. Director of Asia for Human Rights Watch, Brad Adams, stressed that the proposed legislation would permit officials and protest leaders responsible for violence to escape justice. The opposition believes that the Bill is strategically designed to facilitate Mr. Thaksin's return without imprisonment, since he has remained in self-imposed exile since his 2008 conviction for corruption. Initially restricted to ordinary protesters, the amnesty was unexpectedly expanded to include individuals investigated by post-coup agencies. The bill's potential passing has sparked significant political tension, with the Democrat Party vowing continued opposition through street protests and potential legal challenges, including a petition to the Constitutional Court.

Over the next few years, Forest Enterprise Scotland will plant acorns around Loch Trool and the Cree Valley, aiming to grow up to 600,000 young trees and create a large, vibrant habitat. Forester Gareth Ventress explained that upon discovering a bumper crop of acorns they initiated a comprehensive collection strategy, enlisting staff from across Scotland to collect acorns from native oak forests on the national forest estate. The Cree Valley Community Woodland Trust, Borders Forest Trust and Moffat Community Woodlands collaborated in this extensive collection effort to spread native forests across southern Scotland.

By combining acorns from Galloway Forest Park they aim to enhance genetic diversity, linking remnant woodlands and creating robust, disease-resistant forests for the future. The collection process involves laying large felt nets across the wooded surface to facilitate easier picking and to prevent soil contamination. After collection, acorns are carefully sorted and stored with seeds germinated over three to four years. During this period many seeds are graded and deemed infertile, with an estimated 600,000 forgeries to be produced.

These young trees will ultimately establish new oak woodlands and enrich the woodland habitats throughout the Galloway Forest Park, contributing to regional ecological restoration and biodiversity.

Mark Carney highlighted the critical role of green finance in promoting financial stability in a speech at an event in Berlin, notably in emerging markets. He argued that while capital should theoretically flow from developed economies due to higher returns, the contrary happened, driving down yields of bonds in advanced economies. Carney emphasized that sporadic capital flows to emerging economies have been destabilizing and suggested green finance as a strategic solution. He advocated increased issue of green bonds—such as those funding water or renewable power projects—noting their potential to double from $42 billion in 2015, despite currently representing only 1% of global financial institutions. Carney stressed the complex challenge of addressing climate change, warning that it could be too late to act at the time a clear economic incentive emerges. He also warned that an overly rapid transition to a low-carbon economy could potentially damage financial stability. To mitigate these risks, Carney urged companies to disclose the financial risks posed by climate change to their business models and reiterated his earlier warnings about the potential unrecoverability of fossil fuel reserves as governments pursue global warming limits.

Gene Palmer, the second prison worker held in connection with the jail break, is now under surveillance following Joyce Mitchell's earlier arrest for aiding in the escape. The convicted killers Richard Matt and David Sweat used power tools to flee the Clinton Correctional Facility, launching an extensive manhunt. Palmer has been released on bail after facing charges of encouraging prison contraband, tampering with physical evidence and official misconduct. His lawyer Andrew Brockway admitted that Palmer brought meat to the inmates, but claimed that his client was unaware that it contained escape tools. Attorney Andrew Wylie revealed that Mitchell had concealed hacksaw blades and other tools inside the meat which Palmer subsequently delivered to Matt and Sweat in a section of the jail which allowed inmates to prepare their own meals. Law enforcement is currently concentrating their search efforts on a 75-square-mile (194 square kilometers) area in northern New York State where evidence suggests that the fugitives spent time in a hunting cabin near the prison. Given the abundance of weapons in the region, the authorities believe the escapees could be armed and consider them extremely dangerous and cunning.

In the party’s election manifesto, the party proposed a funding floor only after a referendum. The St. David's Day Agreement had described the vote as an "expectation", with Labour Welsh ministers opposing a referendum before a funding agreement. Labour criticised the Conservatives for trying to leverage their position. The manifesto stated explicitly that Conservatives would "introduce a 'funding floor' to protect Welsh relative funding and provide certainty to the Welsh government to plan for the future, contingent on the coming of a referendum on Income Tax powers in the next parliament.

A Welsh conservative spokeswoman clarified to BBC Wales that their commitment to a funding floor is strong with active work underway at the Treasury and Wales Office. She highlighted that the funding floor is not dependent on an income tax referendum, and that their expectation is that the Welsh Assembly should hold a referendum on income tax powers before the next parliament.

Chancellor George Osborne indicated that the proposed funding floor would range between £113 and £116 per person for every £100 spent in England, as noted in economist Gerry Holtham's recommendations. Labour has also vowed to introduce a funding floor, but has not specified a precise figure.

First Minister Carwyn Jones criticized the conservative approach, stating that the vote for the Tories could cost Wales up to £300 million annually. He argued that a fair funding settlement should be unconditional. The Liberal Democrats proposed an independent review of funding arrangements, while Plaid Cymru advocated for an additional £1.2bn annual allocation. The UKIP proposed completely scrapping the existing Barnett formula.

In the crunch of the European competition, Hibs and Glasgow City battled formidable opponents without denouncing their spirit by scores that spoke of uneven competitions. Munich’s surgical precision, on aggregate, overtook Hibs 10-1 while City faced resilient resistance from Eskilstuna United. With pride, Anna Signeul's voice rang to celebrate Scottish football's rise -- two teams on the Champions League stage — a testament to years of dedicated craft and collective aspiration. The journey revealed stark contrasts: Bayern's professional squad, replete with Olympic talent and national squad players, stood as a beacon of excellence against which Scottish teams could measure their potential. Although the results were unforgiving, Signeul saw opportunity in adversity - a chance for young players to view the summit of their ambitions, to understand the rare air of elite competition. Her perspective transcended the immediate results and instead focused on growth, learning and the incremental path to international recognition. In this narrative of sporting endeavor, defeat was not an endpoint, but a milestone on a longer, deeper journey of development and dreams.

The emerging of dockless bike sharing represents a potential shift in urban transportation - oBike launched its service in London this week. Backed by significant venture capital, the company has introduced hundreds of GPS enabled bicycles that can be left with a rear wheel locking mechanism anywhere in the world. Users use bikes through a mobile app, paying a £49 refundable deposit and 50p per half-hour. While oBike aims to complement existing cycle hire schemes and reduce urban emissions, the launch has sparked controversy among the local councils. Hackney and Hammersmith Fulham Councils expressed concerns about bikes blocking pavements and roads and criticizing the lack of prior consultation. Will Norman, London's walking and cycling commissioner, emphasized the need for dockless bike operators to collaborate with the Transport for London and the borough councils to ensure the schemes benefit all Londoners without affecting street users and pedestrians. This scenario highlights the ongoing tension between innovative technology companies and municipal authorities in managing urban mobility solutions.

The Executive Committee of the Confederation of African Football (CAF) chosen Gabon as the host nation on Wednesday, before defeating the rivals of Ghana and Algeria. Jean-Felix Mba Nze, a Gabonese football official, affirmed the nation's commitment and stated : "We will prepare ourselves to win the 2016 Nations Cup" The most significant achievements of Gabon include the quarter-final appearances in 1996 and 2012, the latter being co-hosted with Equatorial Guinea, who first entered the 1970 Nations Cup and qualified for the finals in 1994. Following their early elimination in the most recent tournament, Gabon is poised to host the 2017 Nations Cup independently. Mba Nze, the General Secretary of the Gabonese Federation, emphasized their strategic preparation and noted "Our main challenge is to organize a superior competition compared to 2012. The nation will use two stadiums from the previous finals in Libreville and Franceville, supplemented by new venues in Port Gentil and Oyem, both planned to be completed by August 2016. The selection was met with considerable controversy, with Algerian media expressing significant disappointment and the Ghanaian bid request greater transparency in the selection process. The Confederation of African Football defended its decision by referencing its established protocol for the announcements of host countries.

In the vibrant landscape of British music festivals a passionate tribe of "superfans" emerges - invest in their annual sonic pilgrimages an average of £581. Predominantly male, these devotees transcend casual consumption, often showcasing VIP experiences and engaging in immersive musical journeys. A comprehensive survey of 504 UK residents reveals their profound cultural commitment: they promote music through recommendations, 28% represent festival attendees, and display remarkable independence, with 54% willing to travel solo into the sonic wilderness. Their financial investment reflects their dedication, spending £45 more per event than casual listeners, though their loyalty remains nuanced — 46% criticise the growing corporate homogeneity of these musical events. With over 100 festivals forming the British landscape, from the legendary Glastonbury to intimate jazz celebrations, 3.7 million passionate music lovers fuel an ecosystem supporting 39,000 full-time jobs every year. Despite challenges of unpredictable weather, economic fluctuations, and market saturation the spirit of festival culture prevails. Remarkably, 88% of enthusiasts anticipate returning next year, signalling an unbreakable connection between audience and experience—a testament to the resilient, transformative power of live music.

In a shocking weekend, Cromer was impacted by 37 reported crimes, including a traumatic rape of a teenager, with residents linking these incidents directly to a group of travellers. Suffolk Constabulary had proactively warned Norfolk police about the group's arrival on Friday, with Norfolk acknowledging the notification but claiming that there was "no intelligence" about the group's destination. The grave situation escalated when a late teens woman was sexually assaulted at a bus stop near the shoreline, with police suggesting a possible connection to broader town disturbances. One suspect was arrested and released subsequently under investigation. Local businesses and residents painted a harrowing picture of the group's impact, with a taxi driver described the "travellers of the town" and The Wellington Pub closing after a rowdy group of 30 descended. Eyewitness accounts from business owners like Lee Sale and Ayrun Nessa detailed intimidating and aggressive behavior that left families and community members feeling vulnerable. In response, Cromer's Better Neighbourhood Team has initiated police procedures to address community concerns. The group, comprised of up to 25 caravans, arrived at Runton Road cliff-top car park on Friday before heading on, leaving a community shaken and seeking answers.

In the azure expanse above Brookmans Park a phantom quadcopter sliced through the silence, its white form a fleeting apparition that perilously brushed off the path of an A320. The pilots heart raced as the drone flashed past, a spectral encounter where mere seconds separated safety from catastrophe. Air traffic control echoed the near miss, a whispered testament to the delicate intervention of chance. The rotor arms of this harmless intruder, invisible yet menacing, their presence being a grave violation of sacred protocols in aviation. The drone operator remained a phantom and unrecognised, dancing beyond the limits of regulation, challenging the invisible threads of aerial safety. In that moment that suspended between the sky and potential disaster, the fragile balance of human technology and aerial navigation trembled, a silent reminder of the razor edge between order and chaos.

A survey revealed a stark reality : a quarter of new fathers take no paternity leave, with fewer than one in 10 using more than their two statutory weeks. The Institute of Leadership & Management blamed this on deeply rooted employers' attitudes and fathers' financial concerns. While the government plans to allow parents to share their maternity and paternity leave starting April 2015, the ILM warns that these changes may fall flat without working out workplace culture.

ILM Chief Executive Charles Elvin highlighted the persistent expectation that women, not men, will step back from work. The report highlighted another barrier: low paternity pay. Just 9% of fathers surveyed receive full pay after two weeks. Frances O’Grady of the TUC echoed this, noting that many dads simply can't afford time off.

Currently, fathers receive one or two weeks paid leave, with potential additional time if the mother returns to work. The upcoming changes of the government aim to create more flexibility and to drive a cultural shift that allows working dads to be more involved in their children's early months and helps retain talented women in the workforce.

As with the last year's parade, only the Orangemen and their 13 registered bands can march past St Patrick's Church on Donegall Street in North Belfast. They do so with the sound of a single drum beat, with all music stops 43 metres from the church to ensure that no music is within earshot. A planned protest has been restricted to maximum 50 people at two locations. The Orange Order expressed strong opposition and says that the Commission has become "a mouthpiece of republican propaganda" and is "censoring Protestant heritage" by "invented and absurd" criteria. Nigel Dodds of the DUP Northern Belfast MP labelled the resolve a "bureaucratic monstrosity" that capitulates to republican residents. In contrast, SDLP Assembly member Alban Maginness welcomed the ruling, describing it as judicious and hoped that it would set a respectful tone for the marching season. He noted that the parishioners of St Patrick and Carrick Hill residents have consistently sought fair treatment.

The 34-year-old midfielder has just finished his latest spell in the Indian Super League with Atletico Kolkata. "Having been the player who has come back three times before, I know the appeal and why you would want to come back," said McFadden who confirmed that Motherwell had made him an offer. “And I know that Pearson is exactly the same." Pearson began his career at Fir Park and rejoined Motherwell for a season in 2015 after spells with Celtic, Derby County, Bristol City and Kerala Blasters. He is also a free agent after helping Kolkata finish fourth in the Indian League before winning the title with a play-off victory over his former club Kerala. "We have spoken to him and offered him a deal and are waiting to hear back", said McFadden who thinks Motherwell have a tradition of welcoming former players back. "Pearson would be a great addition on and off the park here. We would love to have him back, so hopefully he makes the right decision and returns home. I know he has one or two things to think about before he makes that decision, but he knows he will be welcomed with open arms here by everyone." The Motherwell have signed the winger Elliot Frear from Forest Green as well as added Reading defender Zak Jules and Everton goalkeeper Russell Griffiths to their loan on the recent days. However, they are still looking to add to their squad before the transfer window closes. "There could be, and we are still working on that," added McFadden. "But we don't have answers from the people we are speaking with, so we will see how it works out.

Kevin McLeod found his lifeless form in Wick Harbour in February 1997, casting a haunting shadow over a community. Although initially considered accidental death, his family harbored deep suspicions, pointing to unexplained injuries that hinted at a more sinister narrative. After a determined dialogue with Chief Constable Phil Gormley, a comprehensive assessment was launched into the circumstances surrounding McLeod's death. Investigators meticulously traced and interviewed witnesses previously unheard of at Wick on that fateful night. June McLeod's resolute pursuit of truth declared to BBC Scotland that if this assessment yielded no revelations, her family would continue its relentless pursuit of justice. Recognizing the deep grief in the McLeod family experience, Detective Chief Superintendent Gareth Blair of Police Scotland acknowledged the enduring impact of Kevin's mysterious death. During his emphasis that this was not a complete reinvesition, Blair described a carefully and nuanced analysis of the accumulated data for decades. Despite the thorough examination, there was no conclusive evidence of criminality, leaving Kevin's death frustratingly unexplained. Police Scotland remains open to new information, however, inviting witnesses to come forward and potentially shed light on this unresolved tragedy.

Matthew Eteson is currently facing trial at Preston Crown Court, charged with manslaughter in relation to Kelly Webster, 36, and Lauren Thornton's deaths. The victims died while sleeping on a boat in Windermere in April 2013. Mr. Eteson, 42, of Hale, Greater Manchester, contests the charge. The family had traveled to Lake District during the Easter weekend to commemorate the birthday of a friend. According to prosecutor Mr. Graham Reeds QC, he removed the generator from the deck and used it to power a 1 kW fan heater. The court was informed that no warning was issued concerning toxic gas accumulation as carbon monoxide sensors had previously been disabled. The mother and daughter both from Leyland, Lancashire, were discovered dead in their sleeping positions aboard the second-hand Bayliner 285 motor cruiser Arniston with fatal levels of carbon monoxide. Mr. Eteson, who had been sleeping in a separate compartment, also experienced carbon monoxide poisoning but regained consciousness and discovered the bodies. Expert testimony revealed that Mr. Eteson, a qualified gas fitter, had made modifications to the generator and his exhaust system which were subsequently deemed to be dangerous. Mr. Webster's mother, Nia Webster, had previously inquired about carbon monoxide detectors, to which Mr. Eteson responded that they were non-functional and that his partner would routinely disconnect a portable detector when cooking. The trial is ongoing.

NHS Blood and Transplantation (NHSBT) emphasised the critical importance of O-negative blood which can be used by patients across blood groups during emergencies. While negative O blood constitutes 12% of transfusions, merely 7% of the population in the UK possesses this blood type. C negative blood is particularly important for ethnic minorities, who are more likely to have this blood type and are at a higher risk of ailments such as sickle cell anaemia and thalassemia, which can significantly impact health outcomes. Although only 2% of the population in Britain is B negative, hospitals have experienced a 6% rise in the use over the previous year. Negative B blood is particularly versatile as it can be administered to both B positive and B negative patients. Donna Batty, the nurse relations manager at NHSBT, has appealed to donors to come forward in the coming days, noting that the stocks of these critical blood groups are less than desired. Currently 4% of the population donate blood to NHSBT and is particularly interested in having first-time donors to expand their donor database. Those uninsured of their blood type can discover it through the donation process. If interested in donating, contact NHSBT at 0300 123 23 23.

Dr. Stephen Farry, the Minister for Employment and Learning, has decided to remove a £1.1million special premium payment that compensated St Mary's University College for its small scale and specialist status. The College with fewer than 1,000 students and an annual income of £4.7m faces significant financial challenges. Protesters argue that the elimination of the premium combined with cuts in the Department of Employment and Learning (DEL) would reduce the College budget by 31%. An additional £32m in the overall budget somewhat softens the blow; the College now anticipates a 26.5% budget reduction—a prospect still deemed unacceptably harsh by principal, Prof Peter Finn. Finn accuses Farry of making an opportunistic decision designed to force the college into one of four proposed solutions for streamlining teacher training in Northern Ireland, none of which preserve St Mary's current autonomy. While committed to maintaining its Catholic ethos, the college is open to "deep sharing" between teachers training institutions, potentially involving cross-campus student exchanges. Prof Finn strongly contests the rationale for the removing of the small scale premia and noting that St Mary, unlike similar English institutions, was not permitted to charge higher tuition fees or increase student numbers. Stranmillis University College faces similar challenges and has been negotiating a merger with Queen's University since 2008, a process that is unresolved and will also be affected by the funding reductions.

The investment, backed by the Welsh government in a total of nearly £15m, will begin production in late 2018. Edwina Hart emphasized the strategic significance of the deal, noting that it would ''for many years safeguard more than 750 skilled Welsh jobs." She highlighted that Wales successfully secured this critical investment in a highly competitive global market, with Ford's decision reflecting the outstanding reputation of the local management and workforce. The Bridgend plant, operating since 1980, has consistently won significant investments of over £2.8bn despite fierce international competition. The Ford presence provides approximately 10,000 jobs in South Wales, with 1,860 currently employed at the facility. Technicians from Essex and Germany collaborated on developing a new fuel-efficient engine range with the investment contingent upon workplace adaptations to improve competitiveness. William Graham, the Welsh Conservative shadow economy minister, viewed the announcement as a testament to the economic recovery efforts of the UK government. The new production arrives opportunely and offsets the imminent ending of Jaguar Land Rover engine manufacturing and securing hundreds of potentially vulnerable jobs. While two hundred fixed-contract workers were previously released following the cease of Volvo engines production, concerns over potential reduction in manufacturing capacity persist. The Welsh government's financial contribution reflects the intensely competitive international landscape of the automotive industry, where government support is often essential to attract and retain manufacturing investments.

S4C stands in the delicate landscape of Welsh broadcasting as a linguistic beacon, primarily from the licence fee, while navigating the turbulent waters of potential budget reviews. The UK ministers have cast their gaze on the BBC with Monmouth MP David Davies promoting S4C as a crucial keeper of Welsh cultural heritage. The future of the channel lies in a precarious balance with governmental discussions oscillating between costs-saving imperatives and cultural preservation. Labour voices warn of possible threats to the channel’s survival, while Culture Secretary John Whittingdale offers tentative reassurances of commitment. Under Davies' leadership, the Welsh Affairs Committee considers an in-depth inquiry into broadcasting and recognizes the profound significance of S4C beyond mere television programming. The channel itself has articulated its resilience, focusing on its unique cultural and economic value during substantial financial loss since 2010 A recent green paper highlights the challenges facing indigenous language services, highlighting the complex intersection of linguistic preservation, public engagement and fiscal responsibility in Wales' media landscape.

The latest Markit report on Jobs for Scotland unveiled a vibrant employment landscape with sharp increases in permanent and temporary placements in April. Temporary demand increased to its highest point in nearly a decade, painting a picture of economic dynamism. This promising scene was also resigned to a critical challenge : declining candidate availability, leaving recruiters facing a skills shortage that threatened to undermine their momentum.

The Recruitment and Employment Confederation (REC) stressed the urgency of addressing this talent gap and called for the future government to protect international workforce access and invest in developing the talents of national jobseekers. The report highlighted the remarkable growth in permanent appointments, completing the third consecutive month of expansion and the fastest growth in 21 months—a performance that clearly outpaced the overall UK trend.

Temporary placements experienced an equally impressive surge since August 2014, reaching levels previously unknown. However, this optimism was tempered by a significant contraction in the worker availability, with permanent staff and temporary candidates declining in months at the most rapid rates.

Sector-specific insights revealed robust demand in IT and computing, nursing/medical care and hospitality while the average salary for both permanent and temporary jobs in Scotland climbed impressively. REC chief executive Kevin Green captured the spirit of the moment by describing a resurgent Scottish employment market navigating Brexit uncertainty with remarkable resilience and strategic adaptability.

Sigrid Kaag addressed the international community as Syria approached a critical deadline for removing its chemical weapons arsenal. The Russian-US Agreement, formulated as a response to a devastating sarin rocket attack near Damascus that took hundreds of lives, orders the complete destruction of Syrian chemical weapons by 30 June. The multinational mission, headed by the United Nations Security Council and the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) has made significant progress in the dismantling of the country's chemical warfare capabilities.

Despite Damascus missing several previous deadlines, a substantial portion of chemical weapons materials have been removed. Ms. Kaag, head of the joint OPCW-UN mission, emphasized the critical nature of extracting from a single site the remaining stockpile. The UN has expressed concern over reports of deployment of chlorine gas by Syrian forces, though this substance was not included in the original disarmament agreement.

According to the OPCW, most of Syria's chemical weapons exist as separate components which become toxic when combined. Ms. Kaag confirmed that the facilities capable of producing and launching chemical weapons have been destroyed. "The Syria chemical weapons programme is no longer in existence as per current declaration to the OPCW under the Chemical Weapons Convention", she stated, highlighting the significant achievements of the mission in neutralizing Syria's chemical weapons infrastructure.

Kim Little, the Seattle Reign player, was voted the second winner of the BBC World Service Award in a supporters'poll and defeated a distinguished shortlist including Gaelle Enganamouit, Amandine Henry, Carli Lloyd and Becky Sauerbrunn. "I'm surprised and extremely humbled to win," the 25-year-old said, expressing optimism about the future of women's football. "The women's football is in a great place. It should progress further."

Little received the award at her club's training ground and was praised by Mary Hockaday, BBC World Service English Controller who acknowledged her outstanding talent. The remarkable 2015 season saw Little lead Seattle with 10 goals, ranking second in the National Women’s Soccer League and helping her team to top the league.

A five-time Premier League champion with Arsenal Ladies and a veteran with 115 goals for Scotland, Little has had a distinguished career highlighted by her Olympic performance in 2012 and multiple individual accolades, including FA women's player of the year in 2010 and the inaugural PFA women player of the year in 2013.

Coach Anna Signeul praised Little as a complete player, describing her as a role model with outstanding speed, technique and versatility. "She's perfect in everything she does on and off the pitch," remarked Signeul, suggesting that it will be a long time before Scotland sees another player of her calibre.

In a breathtaking display of skill, Fraser, currently 90th in the world, engraved his name in the Olympic lore with a spectacular eight-under par 63 and five strokes above his competitors after nine sublime birdies. Amidst Rio 2016 Tournament Shadowed by Zika-virus concerns—which prompted many top-ranked golfers to withdraw—British athlete Justin Rose made history by launching the first Olympic hole-in-one on the challenging par-three fourth, declaring with understated passion that this moment transcended pure luck. Henrik Stenson, fresh from his Open Championship triumph, found himself in second place alongside Canada's Graham Delaet while Rose joined a quintet of formidable competitors berating at four-under. Danny Willett, the recent British champion at the Masters, closed his round in par, while the story of the tournament continued to unfold against the vibrant backdrop of Rio's Olympic stage with the second round awaiting on Friday, promising further athletic drama in this unprecedented golfing spectacle.

On January 30th, 1915, England played in a charity match hosted by former England international and Northampton Saints captain Edgar Mobbs, Scotland. The game aimed at recruiting sportsmen to Mobbs' World War 1 battalion. A commemorative match will take place on 24 January 2015 at Olney Rugby Club and involves players from the East Midlands region against the 1st Battalion of Yorkshire Regiment with the Olney Ladies facing the Army Women's XV.

Edgar Mobbs (1882-1917) was a prominent rugby player and military leader. He was selected for England in 1909 and netting a try on his debut against Australia and seven caps. He advanced from Private to Battalion commander during World War I and fought in Loos, Somme, Arras and Messines. Mentioned twice in Despatches, he was awarded the Distinguished Service Order and died heroically at the Battle of Passchendaele during July 31, 1917.

After retiring from rugby in 1913, Mobbs was initially refused the commission of an officer due to his age. He joined the private profession and became a prominent recruiter, addressing crowds and inspiring over 200 men to enlist. The 1915 international match reportedly motivated hundreds to join the Sportsman’s Battalion, which formed a significant part of the 7th battalion of the Northamptonshire Regiment. Sixteen players who eventually joined Olney perished during the war.

Members of Mobbs' family, including his great-nephew Edgar Mobbs, will attend the commemorative event. Ryland Adkins once noted that Mobbs was "Northamptonshire's finest sportsman and soldier". Jarlath McElroy, chairman of the Olney Rugby Club, described him as a "sporting and war hero." Proceeds from the event will support the military charity of the Soldiers and Sailors' Families Association.

The new charity will manage the National Heritage Collection, which includes Stonehenge and Dover Castle. Currently, the government contributes to the collection £22m annually. The goal is to become eventually self-sufficient for the charity. Other powers such as listing buildings will remain government funded. The new official body, which also will provide advice on planning, has a working name of the National Heritage Protection Service. The new charity will still be called English Heritage, and the 420 sites in the National Heritage collection - including the London Kenwood House and Charles Darwin's Home in Kent - will remain in public ownership. Government funding for the charity will eventually be gradually depleted from 2015 on to nothing, allowing it to generate income from commercial activities and philanthropic donations. Some of the £80m awarded by the government will help to set up the charity so that it is fully operational by March 2015. The planned changes will be subject to consultation The Government s £80m investment and the creation of the new charity aim to maintain the National Heritage Collection for the future, maintain high standards in conservation work and provide an engaging experience of England's heritage. The announcement coincides with potential cuts in funding for museums and the arts of up to 5% in the 2015-2016 spending review.

A friendship in the quiet coastal town of Dunoon turned fatal when Christopher Kelly, a 40-year-old former support worker, violently ended Dorothy Beattie's life, a 51-year-old woman he once cared for. Their once-supportive relationship unraveled in a moment of rage triggered by an alleged slight against his children. Kelly's brutal assault left Ms. Beattie in her own home a scene of devastation discovered by her unsuspecting daughter. After the heinous act, Kelly fled to Edinburgh stealing allegedly from her account, and fleeing through the streets of the city before surrendering to overwhelming guilt. Confessing a GP with haunting words—"I think I killed her"—he revealed a fragmented memory of the attack, blacking out during the fatal struggle. The court recognized the deep tragedy, with Lord Bannatyne the judge acknowledging the senseless loss of life. In the courtroom as Kelly was led away, handcuffed and spoke a belated apology to the victim's daughters, the witness was witness to the devastating consequences of unrelenting anger and momentary violence.

A collision occurred on April 3 at the train station in Penzance shortly after 15:30 BST involving two trains travelling between Penzance and Exeter. The Rail Accident Investigation Branch report revealed that the signaller misjudged platform capacity, believing there was enough space for both trains. Approximately 35 people sustained injuries during the incident. The collision resulted from a practice known as "permissive working," where multiple trains are permitted on the same platform. The moving train, diverted due to maintenance on alternative platform lifts, approached Plymouth at 21 mph along a tight left-hand curve. The driver unexpectedly spotted the stationary train's rear close to the west end of the platform and applied emergency brakes three seconds before the impact, which occurred at about 15 mph. The sudden collision caused standing passengers to be violently thrown into the train rails and on the floor, exacerbating potential injuries.

According to the election commission, the 71-year-old incumbent won 60.75% of the vote, while his nearest rival Kizza Besigye took 35%. The supporters of Mr. Museveni claimed that his opponents offered no viable alternative but Mr. Besigye denounced the results under house arrest as "shame" and urged international rejection. "We just witnessed what must be the most fraudulent electoral process in Uganda," he said. EU observers criticized the poll, noting that the governing party created an "intimidating atmosphere" and citing opposition allegations of voter rigging. While acknowledging the Ugandans'"remarkable determination" to vote, EU Chief Observer Eduard Kukan emphasized that the political dominance of the National Resistance Movement distorted campaign fairness. The election was punctuated by sporadic violence and electoral fraud claims, with social media and messaging apps blocked. Mr. Besigye, detained for allegedly planning to announce results and violate electoral laws, was preparing his fourth presidential challenge against President Museveni, with whom he once shared a close alliance as guerrilla fighters. Museveni, who seized power in 1986 and is credited with restoring national stability, faces increasing criticism for growing authoritarianism. The next significant challenger, former Prime Minister Amama Mbabazi, was also reportedly placed under house arrest.

The proposed development for Chippenham promises 1,000 jobs and an annual economic boost of £31 million, yet the political landscape reveals deep complexity. Of the five parliamentary candidates, one staunchly opposes the project, while three harbor significant reservations. Thousands of local residents have signed petitions both supporting and challenging the proposal passionately. Michelle Donelan acknowledged the nuanced perspectives and criticized the consultation as being inadequate for a development that would "everyone forever change the town". The 72,000 sq m regional centre application awaits Wiltshire Council's scrutiny with candidates revealing their perspectives during a BBC Wiltshire election debate. Andy Newman enthusiastically endorsed the project, which cited the potential for 700 permanent skilled jobs and wage increases. In stark contrast, the Green party candidate Tina Johnston rejected the plans with vehemence and challenged the projected numbers of job hires. Julia Reid of UKIP suggested an alternative road location to minimize impact on the town centre business, while Liberal Democrat Duncan Hames welcomed job prospects but questioned the suitability of the proposed site. The debate shows the complex relationship of the community with potential transformation.

A 31-year-old singer alleged that she had been denied service by a black cab driver and subject to discriminatory language. The incident follows her previous public commentary on migrants' conditions in Calais. The Licensed Taxi Drivers Association condemned this potentially abusive behaviour and requested that Transport for London conduct a thorough investigation. The artist shared their experience on social media, declaring that the driver instructed her to find an immigrant to provide transportation, an encounter she described as providing an insight into systemic discrimination. While some social media users questioned the authenticity of her account, she maintained the authenticity of her experience. The general secretary of the association said that such conduct would potentially threaten the professional credentials of a driver. This incident occurred in context of the artist’s recent humanitarian work, including an emotional encounter with a young Afghan refugee on a national broadcast during which she expressed collective national remorse for historic geopolitical actions affecting vulnerable populations.

While not disclosed the deal for the 25-year-old world cup runner-up is believed to be around £8m. Fernandez joins a four-year contract and is expected to be included in Swansea's squad to face Burnley on Saturday pending international clearance. Having started four of Argentina's matches during their electrifying World Cup Final run, he arrives as a strategic replacement for Chico Flores who recently moved to Qatar.

The centre-back expressed unbridled enthusiasm about his new opportunity, revealing: "It has always been my dream to play in the Premier League - it is the best in the world - and I'm grateful to Swansea for giving me this chance." After consulting with his teammates Michu and Jordi Amat he was assured of the club’s exceptional reputation. Michu described Swansea as a family club with a relaxed atmosphere - further solidifying Fernandez's excitement.

Manager Garry Monk praised the acquisition, showing Fernandez's pedigree after playing in Napoli and representing Argentina in the World Cup. "He's a good size, a very good footballer, and someone who will suit Swansea City," he noted. "The type of players that we seek are those who add quality to the squad, and he will do that definitely"

Despite returning from World Cup duties recently and still building match fitness, Fernandez represents a promising addition to the defensive line-up of the Swans.

New shots of Charlene Downes, who was last seen in the city centre of Blackpool, were discovered during a review of CCTV footage. Her body has never been found. Lancashire Police released the images to mark the anniversary of her disappearance in 2003 as part of their ongoing murder investigation. Charlene is shown on November 1st at 15:25 GMT near Bank Hey Street with her sister Rebecca walking toward the Coral Island Amusement Park. She went home later that evening, but returned to the centre of Blackpool, which was the last time she was seen. Police reported that the clothes she is wearing on the footage are identical to those she had wore when she went missing. Supt Andy Webster stated that officers are investigating potential links between Charlene's disappearance and child sexual exploitation in Blackpool with plans to identify and possibly prosecute suspects. A previous trial for her murder ended without conviction and the Independent Police Complaints Commission found evidence-gathering errors in the initial investigation. In connection with Charlene's death, no one has been convicted and the case remains unresolved.

Julia Knight, 56, denying that she tried to murder Irene Robson, 81, in October 2014 at Horton Hospital in Banbury while claiming the administration of insulin. At the Oxford Crown Court, she said that her actions were motivated by a desire to prevent her mother's discharge from the hospital. Ms Knight also refuses to pose intently grievous bodily harm, and emphasizes her concern for the continued care of her mother. She expressed remorse, stating: "I felt terrible knowing I would make my mother unwell. It was a profoundly misguided action that I would rescind if possible." The defendant admitted to providing false statements to the police during initial interrogation in January. The evidence presented revealed that Ms Knight had a forged insulin prescription from a Sainsbury's in Banbury. When asked about her initial refusal of injecting her mother by defense counsel Simon Mayo QC, she responded that she recognized the gravity of her actions and felt ashamed. Prosecutor John Price QC suggested an intention to administer a potentially lethal dose to which Ms Knight maintained she never intended her mother's death. The court was also informed about a previous suicide attempt by insulin injection in 2006. While Ms Robson passed away in September, the jury was told that this fact was immaterial to the current proceedings. The trial is currently on.

The Korea Space Launch Vehicle-1 (KSLV-1) blasted from the Naro Space Center, marking a pivotal moment for South Korea's space ambitions. Science Minister Lee Ju-ho has confirmed the satellite's successful deployment into its designated orbit, collecting crucial climate data. This launch came weeks after North Korea's controversial satellite placement, which had drawn international criticism. After previous failures in 2009 and 2010, the 140-tonne Naro rocket from South Korea developed in partnership with Russia represented the third launch attempt of the country. Officials reported that the rocket reached its target altitude and successfully deployed the Science and Technology Satellite-2C 540 seconds after launch. "We have now leapt a step to become a space-power nation," Lee declared, noting the significance of this accomplishment. While previously South Korea relied on international launches, this mission marked its first independent space endeavor. The satellite was to meet up with its ground station the following morning with operators poised to assess the mission's full success. The launch carried additional weight in the context of regional tensions, especially following the recent launch of a rocket from North Korea and subsequent nuclear testing plans which had prompted UN sanctions and international concern.

He threatened to quit the Premier League club within 24 hours if the bid for the name change failed and that Football Association turned it down in April. "When I say something, I mean it," declared the 75-year-old Egyptian on Thursday. He revealed that the club had been put on sale 22 hours after the decision of FA five months ago. Allam said an appeal against the rejection of the name change was filed with the Court of Arbitration for Sport. "We earlier this year stated that the club would be for sale should our attempt to promote Hull Tigers globally as a brand name and as a playing name be blocked," he explained. "As a result of the FA decision on 9 April, I announced in 22 hours on 10 April that Hull City is to be sold." Allam, who took control of the club in December 2010 was pressed on what he would do if a buyer could not be found and the legal appeal was dismissed. She gave it away. It means that I'm out of my place. Have I ever said anything and gone back on it?" He said. Allam noted that he and his son Ehab, who is the club's interim executive director, would remain committed to the club for the time being. "If the appeal comes first, OK, no harm done. "If the sale comes first, they are sold," he said. He was non-committal to potential buyer interest and suggested that he may stay on if the appeal was successful. The Chairman acknowledged that manager Steve Bruce and his players needed stability, but highlighted his investment during the transfer window, which included the signing of Uruguay striker Abel Hernandez for a reported club record fee of £10m. Hull reached FA Cup final last season, losing 3-2 to Arsenal after going two ahead, and finishing their first season back in the Premier League after promotion from the Championship. In the table, they are ninth with four points from three matches of the new season of 2014-15.

Scot Higgins, a 19-year-old prodigy with Celtic roots, carved his path through Dens Park and made four passionate appearances for Dundee last season. Alan Power, a 29-year-old veteran United Kingdom Under-21s international, leaves Lincoln City after a remarkable journey of over 250 league matches. Converging at Rugby Park, both warriors have pledged their spirits to a two-year quest with the arrival of Power awaiting the final clearance. "This club breathes ambition", whispered Higgins, his eyes reflecting hope and determination. Manager Lee McCulloch sees a raw talent forged in Celtic's legendary academy as a beacon of potential to illuminate the pitch. McCulloch noted that "His journey through Dundee tempered his skills and his growth will be the heartbeat of our club. Power echoed this sentiment with his voice resonant with anticipation: "The club's history calls to me and the vision of the manager is a siren song I cannot resist." After having witnessed Power’s leadership during Lincoln’s electrifying FA Cup run, McCulloch praised his aggressive spirit and potential for mentorship. As the 5 August clash against St Johnstone beckons, Kilmarnock is poised to write its next chapter.

England were impacted significantly by injuries in the back row, with key players James Haskell, Sam Jones, Mike Williams and the versatile Maro Itoje out of contention. Harrison, who played only half an hour in the recent test match against Australia in Sydney, has reported substantial improvements. Head coach Jones highlighted Harrison's recent performance against Castres as exceptional, positioning him as the current preferred open-side flanker.
