Despite selecting six uncapped players in the 33-man squad, Jones tempered expectations regarding their immediate international prospects, particularly against South Africa. The team is set to travel to Portugal for a training camp with a primary focus on maintaining player fitness and preventing injuries. Jones stressed the delicate balance between rigorous preparation and player welfare and stressed the need to train with intensity while minimizing potential risk.

Borrowing the names of organisations such as the Nasa and the Environmental Protection Agency, these rogue accounts are launching a passionate rebellion against President Trump. Mr Trump, who dismissed climate change as a hoax, is now facing a fierce digital insurgency. The @RogueNASA account boldly declares itself as the "unofficial 'Resistance' team of NASA", promising "facts with a sharp edge of defiance ". BBC News reached out to the provocative Environmental Protection Agency @ActualEPAFacts account, which emerged as a strong voice of scientific integrity. They revealed a compelling mission : ensuring critical climate research and scientific truth continues to be shared under the Trump administration, despite being silenced by administrative gagging orders. Reports suggest the Trump administration sought to suppress government agencies, effectively strangling public communication. The official EPA Twitter account has remained eerie silence since the day before the inauguration of Mr Trump. These alternative accounts have exploded in popularity, with @RogueNasa attracting over 370,000 followers and @AltNatParkSer converging an astonishing. Similar rogue accounts have emerged for the US Department of Agriculture, the Forest Service and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, united by a common language of resistance and a determination to protect scientific truth. Their posts blend rigorous scientific information with pointing criticism, a digital rebellion unprecedented against the political suppression of scientific discourse.

British Marine, the vanguard of the leisure, superyacht and small commercial marine industry, unveiled a compelling narrative of maritime economic resilience. The sector's revenues soared to £605m in superyachts and for the first time since 2008-2009 reached the historic £3bn threshold, a 1.6% surge. Despite the promise of growth, Brexit’s looming uncertainty cast a nuanced shadow over future prospects. The industry’s trajectory traced a remarkable recovery from its nadir in 2011-2012 when revenues dipped to £2.85bn and gradually climbed through strategic reinvention. This revival of machinery and equipment was accompanied by a vibrant jump in the rental and charter boat sales. While exports dropped marginally by 0.7% to £882m, the pound's post-referendum depreciation paradoxically enhanced overseas purchasing power. Howard Pridding, the CEO of British Marine affirmed the industry's robust spirit and emphasised continued revenue growth and expanding employment. Notwithstanding economic volatility, the sector remained resilient, with global standings positioning marine industries as the fourth largest by turnover. Sunseeker and Princess emerged as the UK's main superyacht manufacturer, symbolizing British maritime innovation and entrepreneurial energy.

The deal announced by Russia to establish four "de-escalation zones" is supported by Turkey and Iran. The Syrian opposition group expressed skepticism about the agreement. The special UN ambassador to Syria, Staffan de Mistura, stressed the importance of the deal, given its implementation by three countries. The zones aim to halt attacks and facilitate the return of refugees and delivering human aid. The four zones will remain in place for six months, and the borders to be finalized by Russia, Iran and Turkey by 4 June. Russian deputy defence minister Alexander Fomin stated that since May 1 no bombing raids in these areas, while maintaining the right to strike Islamic State militants elsewhere in Syria. The Syrian government supports the plan, though it is not a signatory. The Astana talks were intended to reinforce a ceasefire which was originally agreed in December. The Syrian conflict started in 2011 and has resulted in over 300,000 deaths.

In the hallowed halls of the Senate, history unfolded with a delicate dance of democracy as legislators cast their votes on a transformative bill that would redefine love and family. After fourteen hours of passionate discourse, the chamber embraced marriage equality by a razor-thin margin of 33 to 27, with three abstentions. The legislation championed by the progressive government of President Cristina Fernandez not only recognized same-sex unions but also granted a profound right of adoption. Outside the streets were pulsed with rival demonstrations, a testament to the seismic cultural impact of the law. Maria Rachid, who is leading the Argentine Federation of Lesbians, Gays, Bisexuals and Transsexuels, has proclaimed a vision of justice declaring that Argentina would now stand as a more inclusive homeland for all families. The moment transcended mere legal procedure and was a symphony of social evolution, where Love's boundless nature triumphed over historical constraints and marked a landmark victory for human dignity in Latin America's progressive landscape.

The political landscape is crinkling with anticipation as parties scramble to select their champions for the coming election. The 54 SNP sitting MPs are hanging in a delicate balance, with the fate of controversial figures Natalie McGarry and Michelle Thomson in the balance. The Labour executive is about to make its strategic moves, while the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats have already begun positioning their candidates. The snap election of Prime Minister Theresa May, ratified by Parliament, has set the political wheels into motion. McGarry and Thomson now, standing alone in their opposition, face potential replacement if the SNP seeks to fill crucial gaps in its electoral armor. Activists are already jockeying for position, particularly in Glasgow East and Edinburgh West with party machines working overtime to secure their preferred nominees. The urgency is palpable, with Labour issues a digital rally cry and Scottish party leaders like Kezia Dugdale expressing readiness for the impending election battle. Veteran politicians like Ian Murray and David Mundell have launched their campaign defenses swiftly, while new competitors like Douglas Ross and Jo Swinson are preparing for high-stakes rematches that could redefine Scotland's political representation. The stage is set for a dramatic electoral battle with each party maneuvering to secure their strongest possible lineup.

Oxfam advocates for the resettlement of 10% of the 4.8 million Syrians who were displaced by civil war by the end of the year, highlighting that only 1,4% have been helped so far. Ahead of the UN talks in Geneva, the organisation criticized Britain's plan to resettle 20,000 Syrians by 2020, despite Britain's humanitarian aid pledge of £2.3 billion which ranks it the second largest bilateral donor after the US. While acknowledging Britain's financial generosity, Oxfam says that economically advanced nations must assume greater responsibility for refugees, especially from Lebanon and Jordan. The charity's analysis of 28 OECD countries reveals that they promise to accept nearly 130,000 Syrian refugees, but only 67,000 actually arrived. According to Oxfam, the 10% targeted for resettlement represents the most vulnerable population of the United Nations. Only Canada, Germany and Norway have exceeded their fair share of resettlement, with five additional nations sharing more than half of their allocated resources. By contrast, the UK is expected to take 22% of its fair share, the US 7%, and France 4%. Oxfam GB Chief Executive Mark Goldring condemned the international response and stated: "It is shocking that while many people continue to flee Syria, most countries have failed to provide a safe home for the most vulnerable."

Newsweek became a weekly magazine reporting on global events in 1933 and over its 80-year history has witnessed profound transformations in the media landscape. The print edition will end on 31 December and reflect the industry-wide shift towards digital platforms as traditional print advertising declines. The subscription base of Newsweek has decreased dramatically from a peak of over 3 million today to 1.5 million, forcing the publication to transition to a digital-only format.

The digital subscription-based version of Newsweek Global is strategically targeting the burgeoning tablet market, which has grown from 13 million users to 70 million in the United States. Despite the promising digital landscape, analysts warn that distinguishing in an increasingly competitive online environment will present significant challenges.

Two years ago, the publication merged with The Daily Beast, with founder Tina Brown on the impressive growth of the website to over 15 million unique monthly visitors - representing a 70% increase from last year. Brown emphasized that the decision to exit print media is not a reflection of journalistic quality, but a response to the complex economic realities of print publishing and distribution.

Historically, Newsweek ranked as the second-largest news weekly in the United States, just behind Time Magazine. However, declining circulation and advertising revenue finally precipitated its transformation, signalling a wider industry trend towards digital consumption.

Spencer Flower, a 72-year-old Conservative councillor, found himself in legal action after a housing strategy while serving as the non-executive director of Synergy Housing Ltd. Despite declaring his interest before the meeting he was found guilty of voting illegally in a 2013 East Dorset core strategy debate where potential benefits for his associated charity organization were in question. Flower was handed a six-month conditional discharge and ordered to pay £930 in costs at Bournemouth Magistrates' Court, and maintained his innocence, arguing that the court's decision was based on a technicality and stressed the absence of personal gain. The core strategy, which included redevelopment plans for Wimborne, potentially affected Synergy's housing portfolio. Flower had stepped aside as the leader of the Dorset County Council to address the charges, with two other charges previously dismissed. A spokesperson for Christchurch Borough Council and East Dorset District Council noted Flower's continued membership in the council, with his political future in doubt until the next local elections.

For a third week, Bowie's celestial swan song, Blackstar, reigned supreme, with Best of Bowie, Hunky Dory and Ziggy Stardust dominating the Top 10. At two Adele held steady while Suede, steeped in Bowie's musical legacy, burst onto the scene at number six. Its anti-Beautiful Rihanna release failed to chart after its Tidal release and was deemed by Official Chart Company rules unqualified. Yet in just 48 hours, her collaboration with Drake, Work, had inked the singles chart at 13. Jonas Blue's tropical reimagining of Tracy Chapman's Fast Car jumped to three, eclipsing the original's historic performances. Shawn Mendes continued his meteoric rise with Stitches, outselling Justin Bieber by 13,000 copies and dominating streaming with 3.51 million plays. Elle King's Graham Norton Show appearance catapulted Ex's'Oh's from 64 to 15 while Love Stuff rocketed 40 places to 18th place. The musical legacy of Bowie s strengthened further with Nothing Has Changed, Heroes, Diamond Dogs, Station to Station and Scary Monsters populating the top 40.

On Sunday, Mr. Joshua told his congregation that he "saw" a woman winning. After Donald Trump's decisive victory on Tuesday, visitors to the preacher's Facebook page noticed that the prophecy had disappeared. He is known as the "prophet" to his followers and is one of Nigeria's most influential evangelists and popular throughout Africa, with many top politicians among his flock. The US election prediction was broadcast on Mr. Joshua's TV Channel Emmanuel TV and uploaded to YouTube. A section of the "prophecy" was initially posted on his Facebook Page but was later removed. "Vine days ago I saw the President of America with a narrow win... What I truly saw was a woman," it reads. TB Joshua hopped on Twitter across Nigeria, Ghana and South Africa as people posted memes about his prediction. His Facebook post of Wednesday drew mixed reactions, with some questioning the deleted prophecy and others maintaining a staunch support for the move. Many believe that TB Joshua has supernatural powers of healing and prophecy, a reputation bolstered by endorsements by prominent African leaders like Ghana's late President John Atta Mills, Tanzanian President John Magufuli and Malawi's former leader Joyce Banda.

Participants in the annual event have to craft the most imaginative and convincing lie imaginable in five minutes. George Kemp from Maryport, Cumbria, has clinched this year despite suffering a chest infection and spinning a wild tale of Donald Trump and his wife in an underwater hotel. His narrative began with his dad transforming his old bubble car into a tiny submarine and embarking on a journey to the Isle of Man where he surely encountered famous figures in a Scottish submarine constructed idiosyncraticly of shortbread tins. In a comedic twist, he claimed that Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond had even sold these whimsical vessels to the United States. Mike Naylor, known as ''Monkey Liar'' was the champion from Wasdale of last year, secured second place, with Helen Jordan claiming third place. The contest, a longstanding tradition dating back to the 19th century, honors Will Ritson, a legendary local landlord known for his outrageous stories, such as claims that turnips were so massive they required quarrying and could double as sheep sheds. Held at the Bridge Inn in Santon Bridge before a discerning panel of judges and an enthusiastic audience, the event excludes politicians and legal professionals in the art of fabrication deemed to be too skilled, ensuring a level playing field for creative storytellers.

The impressive 3-52 of Mark Footitt saw the visitors lose five wickets before lunch with Sam Curran that England defeated former opener Haseeb Hameed for a second-ball duck. However, Tom Clark's decisive 108 not out and Shivnarine Chanderpaul's steady 85 not out reconstructed the visitors’ innings. On his century he pulled six with command at the close of the day. The West Indies International Chanderpaul and Ryan McLaren worked together for a 55-run partnership that stabilized the innings after the early setbacks before Gareth Batty's dismissal brought McLaren to the crease. The pair then shared an unbroken 172-run partnership where Clark—batting at number eight—swiftly overcame Chanderpaul’s score. Although bad light prevented play during the evening session, it did not impede Clark's progress. The 26-year-old whose previous highest score was 84 no result struck 17 fours and three sixes. Lancashire's remarkable turnaround was particularly noteworthy, having been reduced within 22 overs to five wickets down. Footitt, who had taken eight wickets in Surrey's season opener against Warwickshire, dismissed Alex Davies,'s stand-in captain Liam Livingstone and Dane Vilas, while the Curran brothers each took a wicket during the early assault. Later, Clark commented on his performance, expressing satisfaction with the team position and acknowledgement of the challenges ahead.

For the year to August, sales increased to €34.2bn (£28.8bn) at the company. The chain expanded its retail presence by opening 12 new stores, contributing to a 7.1% total sales growth, though that represents a decrease from the previous year's 11% growth. The Like-for-like sales rose 5%, consistent with the performance of the prior year. The privately-owned Swedish group reported significant market growth in Poland with sales soaring about 20%, establishing it as the most rapidly expanding market of the company. Germany and the United States remain the largest markets. This year Ikea plans to launch stores in India and Serbia, with its global footprint increasing to 340 stores in 28 countries. The company has temporarily suspended expansion in Russia pending the resolution of outstanding legal matters. In the United Kingdom, Ikea maintains 19 stores, with planned additions in Exeter, Sheffield and southeast London. Along with new store openings, the company introduced 19 global "click and collect" locations, adapting to changing consumer preferences. Ikea recently launched online sales, offering home delivery and collection options, a strategic departure from its traditional in-store model. The UK furniture market continues to see robust online growth, with digital sales increasing 15 % and delivering over 12% of the total expenditure. The company's leadership has predicted annual sales reaching €50bn by 2020 and has recently begun publishing sales and profits. A museum commemorating the company's heritage has opened in Almhult, Sweden, the site of the first store opened in 1958 by founder Ingvar Kamprad.

On March 30, 1981 a chilling moment of violence erupted outside a Washington hotel and destroyed the early days of Ronald Reagan’s presidency. John Hinckley Jr. unleashed a barrage of gun fire, critically wounding President Reagan who was shot in the lung and leaving Press Secretary James Brady with devastating brain damage that would confine him for life in a wheelchair. The shocking assassination attempt reverberated across the nation, with Reagan miraculously recovering and Brady finally dying in 2014, his death ruling murder. The two additional law enforcement officers were also injured in the traumatic incident. Hinckley, driven by an obsessive infatuation with actress Jodie Foster, was found not guilty by reason of insanity and admitted to psychiatric treatment. After decades of careful monitoring, US district judge Paul Friedman determined that Hinckley, now 61, had had no active mental illness symptoms since 1983 and was no longer a threat to himself or others. The Court's extensive evaluation ultimately led to his conditional release, which allowed him to spend significant time under strict supervision at his mother's Virginia home.

The collapse of Emcol 2008 Ltd, the abattoir in Haverfordwest, sent shockwaves through the local agricultural community and left a financial crater of £660,000 spread among more than 230 creditors. The industrial landscape was marred by mounting debts and unpaid invoices, with one yakder facing a staggering loss of over £107,000. Newport dairy farmer John Sollis mourned the devastating impact of the closure, describing it as a catastrophic blow that sprang through the rural economy. Liquidator Gary Stones revealed a precarious financial road, with any hope of unsecured creditor payments hanging by a thread, dependent on collection of a £470,000 debt from an Irish firm. The extinction of the abattoir forced farmers like Sollis to transport livestock and injured animals further afield, adding costs and eroding already thin profit margins. NFU Cymru President Stephen James lamented the loss, noting the grim new reality that injured cows must be shot on farm premises - a stark testament to the vulnerability of the industry. Director Helen Lewis acknowledged the company's struggles, citing escalating operational costs and significant outstanding debts, while expressing heartfelt sympathy for the farmers whose livelihoods were now dramatically changed.

In the shadowy streets of Bermondsey, a tragic tale of young love, jealousy and a fatal confrontation unfolded when Ben Purdy was brutally killed after challenging his ex-partner of his girlfriend about menacing messages that lingered like a dark cloud after their relationship ended. Andrew Bayne, 37, and his nephew Michael Bagnall, 22, were found guilty of murder and sentenced for the violence at the Old Bailey. The court heard how Purdy and his friends, Callum Malone and Jack Walker, initially confronted Bagnall and triggered a volatile chain of events that would culminate in a deadly pursuit across the neighborhood. In a chilling moment of revenge, Bayne Purdy tracked down in Mossington Gardens and fired a fatal shot in his head, destroying his life and future. Despite Bagnall's new relationship, his lingering resentment had fueled a campaign of threatening messages that ultimately led to this devastating confrontation. As the guilty verdict rang out, Bagnall's explosive incident revealed the raw, uncontrolled emotions that had set this tragic sequence in motion, a stark reminder of the devastating consequences of unchecked rage and jealousy.

Masai Graham won with the gag: "My Dad suggested I register for a donor card, he's a man after my heart." The festival's best jokes were selected by a panel of 10 judges and then voted on by 2,000 people. Previous winners include Tim Vine, Stewart Francis and Zoe Lyon. Graham, from West Bromwich, claimed victory after being shortlisted in 2014 and 2015. Comedian Stuart Mitchell placed second with the joke: 'Why is it old people say 'there's no place like home ', yet when you put them in one...' Judges reviewed an average of 60 comedy performances and evaluated over 3,600 minutes of material before selecting their preferred jokes. In order to ensure an unbiased selection, comic's name and show were not revealed during the voting process. Steve North, general manager of Dave, said that the Fringe is known for discovering new comedian talent, with the Top 10 this year featuring both returning and emerging performers. Voters also selected the most "groanworthy" jokes, including Adam Hess' line: "In France J-Lo is called 'I have water'" and Darren Walsh's gag: "What are you calling three members of Abba in a French slaughterhouse? "Abba - trois."

The Halle Orchestra is set to revolutionise the education in Stoke-on-Trent by launching a groundbreaking school that places music at the heart of learning. Designed for September 2020, this innovative institution will welcome students age seven to 19 to offer an extraordinary educational experience where music is not just an extracurricular activity but a pathway to academic excellence. Students will dive deep into music, spending 40% of their time in specialized classes, alongside the Halle choir, the Halle Youth Orchestra and the Halle for Youth. Imagine masterclasses with professional musicians, backstage access to concerts and artists in residence who breathe life into every lesson. John Summers Chief Executive believes this approach will dramatically "rise aspirations" across all academic subjects. Building on a successful model in Bremen, Germany, where an orchestra transformed the culture of a comprehensive school, the Halle shows that music can be a powerful catalyst for educational transformation. Until Department for Education approves, this school promises more than an institution — it's a symphony of learning where every note has the potential to inspire academic achievement.

Heading the somber procession were survivors and loved ones of the 32 souls that were tragically lost in the devastating terrorist attacks on Belgium's airport and metro station. The Belgian broadcaster described the march as a poignant, hushed tribute to those whose lives were brutally ended. Originally scheduled for a week after the 22 March attacks, the march was delayed due to security concerns. Relatives of the victims, alongside paramedics and airport staff deeply wounded by the tragedy, joined representatives from various religious communities in a powerful display of unity. As they walked a path of grief and resilience, mourners carried delicate flowers, symbols of remembrance and hope. The procession wound through Molenbeek, the neighborhood linked to both the perpetrators of the attacks in Brussels and Paris before reaching the makeshift memorial outside the bourse of the city. Hassan Bousetta, one of the organizers of the march, passionately declared : "When our defenseless fellow citizens are struck down ruthlessly, every citizen must rise to express their collective outrage and solidarity." Despite a modest draw of fewer than anticipated 15,000 participants, the march stood as a testament to human strength in the face of terror. The Islamic state claimed responsibility for these brutal attacks that had also claimed 130 lives in Paris. While the Belgian authorities have made numerous arrests, questions persist over the systemic failures that allowed such catastrophic attacks to occur.

Cairn Energy has received government approval in Senegal to initiate an evaluation plan for its offshore exploration blocks. The company estimates potential oil reserves that exceeded one billion barrels following two significant discoveries in the area last year. The evaluation plan will commence with a comprehensive 3D seismic survey and a multi-well exploration and appraisal program for later this year. Cairn, based in Edinburgh, holds 40% interest in three offshore blocks (Sangomar Deep, Sangomar Offshore, Rufisque Offshore) alongside its partners ConocoPhillips (35%), FAR Ltd (15%) and Petrosen, Senegal National Oil Company (10% in exploration phase). Cairn has initiated international arbitration proceedings against the Indian Government over a tax dispute, challenging a $1.6bn tax bill in 2006-07. The company has been prevented from acquiring its 10% remaining shareholding in Cairn India Limited, with the value of its stake declining from $1bn in December 2013 to $526m by 30 June. This reduced valuation prompted a loss of $177.1 million, resulting in a loss of $230m post-tax. Despite generating no revenue and focusing solely on exploration, Cairn maintains a robust cash balance of $725 million, though its share price experienced a 5% decline.
